text: I think it's very important to do a core job really well at any company, but it's equally important to have curiosity and be open to serendipity. I think Zoom makes it harder, but it's very important to understand what else is going on at the company, what else people are working on, and just keep talking to people and build relationship with the company, because those are what will lead to the next set of opportunities.
speaker: Gokul Rajaram
context: Lenny asks Gokul about his journey to becoming a tech leader. Gokul shares how he discovered Google AdSense by walking around the office after hours and finding engineers working on a side project, eventually becoming their part-time PM. He explains that great career opportunities often don't come from linear progression but from staying curious about what's happening around you and building relationships across the company.
vocabulary_highlights: lead to the next set of opportunities
text_ko: 어떤 회사에서든 핵심 업무를 정말 잘하는 건 굉장히 중요해요. 하지만 똑같이 중요한 건 호기심을 갖고 우연한 기회(serendipity)에 열려 있는 자세예요. Zoom 때문에 그런 게 더 어려워졌다고 생각하지만, 회사에서 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지, 동료들이 어떤 걸 하고 있는지 파악하고 계속 사람들과 대화하면서 관계를 쌓아 가는 게 매우 중요해요. 그런 것들이 다음 기회로 이어지거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得在任何公司把核心工作做好都很重要，但同样重要的是要保持好奇心，对意外机会保持开放态度。我觉得Zoom让这变得更难了，但了解公司里还在发生什么事，别人在做什么项目，多跟人聊天，在公司里建立人脉关系，这些都非常重要，因为这些才会给你带来下一波机会。
text_es: Creo que es súper importante hacer muy bien tu trabajo principal en cualquier empresa, pero igual de importante es tener curiosidad y estar abierto a las oportunidades que surgen de casualidad. Creo que Zoom lo hace más difícil, pero es clave entender qué más está pasando en la empresa, en qué más está trabajando la gente, y simplemente seguir hablando con las personas y construir relaciones dentro de la compañía, porque eso es lo que te va a llevar al siguiente grupo de oportunidades.

text: I think many opportunities don't come linearly just working in your job and making sure you get promoted. That's not how I think great careers are built. I think great careers are built by knowing a lot of people doing great work so they know and want you on their teams, and just waiting for serendipity and then seizing it and jumping.
speaker: Gokul Rajaram
context: Gokul continues explaining his career philosophy after sharing how random encounters led to major opportunities like joining Square. He argues against the traditional approach of focusing solely on your current role to get promoted, instead advocating for building a broad network within your company and being ready to act when unexpected opportunities arise.
text_ko: 저는 많은 기회가 그냥 직장 생활만 하고 승진만 하면 알아서 오는 건 아니라고 생각해요. 그렇게 해서 훌륭한 커리어가 만들어지는 건 아니에요. 좋은 커리어는 훌륭한 일을 하는 사람들을 많이 알고 있어서 그 사람들이 당신을 알고 팀에 데려가고 싶어 하게 만드는 것, 그리고 우연한 기회(serendipity)를 기다렸다가 그 기회가 오면 과감히 잡고 뛰어드는 것으로 만들어진다고 봐요.
text_zh: 我觉得很多机会不是靠在一个岗位上埋头苦干、等着升职就能得到的。真正牛的职业发展不是这么来的。我认为要想事业做得好，就得认识很多厉害的人，自己活儿也得干得漂亮，这样他们才会想要你加入他们的团队。然后就是等机缘巧合，一旦碰上了就得抓住，该跳就跳。
text_es: Creo que muchas oportunidades no llegan de forma lineal solo trabajando en tu puesto y asegurándo que te asciendan. Así no es como se construyen las grandes carreras. Pienso que las grandes carreras se construyen conociendo a mucha gente, haciendo un trabajo excelente para que te conozcan y te quieran en sus equipos, y simplemente esperando a que llegue la casualidad afortunada (serendipity) para entonces aprovecharla y lanzarte.

text: I think the biggest one is, the founder becomes too tactical and disempowers their team. I think the founder thinks they know what customers want. I think they don't empower their teams enough and they basically just tell the engineers what to build. And I think that leads to teams that are basically tactically just shaping feature after feature without truly solving problems.
speaker: Gokul Rajaram
context: Lenny asks about common pitfalls in startup product development processes. Gokul identifies the biggest mistake as founders who micromanage by dictating specific features rather than presenting problems for their teams to solve. This creates what he calls a 'feature factory' where teams build features without understanding their impact on customer behavior.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 제일 큰 문제는 창업자(founder)가 너무 전술적(tactical)으로 변해서 팀의 자율성을 빼앗는다는 점이에요. 창업자는 자기가 고객이 뭘 원하는지 안다고 생각하고, 팀에 충분히 권한을 주지 않은 채 그냥 엔지니어(engineers)들에게 무엇을 만들어야 할지 지시해요. 그러다 보니 팀은 근본적인 문제를 해결하기보다 전술적으로 기능(feature)들만 잇달아 만드는 수준에 그치게 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得最大的问题就是，创始人管得太细了，把团队的权力都收走了。创始人总觉得自己最懂客户要什么，不给团队足够的自主权，基本上就是直接告诉工程师该做什么。这样搞下去，团队就变成纯执行的了，一个功能接一个功能地堆，根本解决不了真正的问题。
text_es: Creo que el problema más grande es que el fundador se vuelve demasiado operativo y le quita poder a su equipo. El fundador piensa que sabe lo que quieren los clientes. No empodera lo suficiente a sus equipos y básicamente solo les dice a los ingenieros qué construir. Y eso lleva a equipos que están solo desarrollando funcionalidad tras funcionalidad de manera táctica, sin realmente resolver problemas de fondo.

text: Engineers are by far the most expensive resources in the company. By far, right? I mean if you look at the composition of engineers versus... And PMs versus any other function, it's two to three, equity, cash, everything. And if you think of it that way, then if you're not caring and feeding and not leveraging this amazing most expensive resource, well, that's a crime.
speaker: Gokul Rajaram
context: Lenny asks when startups should hire their first PM, and Gokul explains why it's typically when you have 8-10 engineers. He emphasizes that engineers are the most expensive resource at any company in terms of compensation and equity, so if a founder doesn't have bandwidth to properly manage and direct this expensive team, they need to hire a PM to ensure these resources are being leveraged effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: leveraging this amazing most expensive resource
text_ko: 엔지니어(engineers)는 회사에서 단연 가장 비싼 자원이에요. 정말 그렇죠? 엔지니어와 프로덕트 매니저(PMs)를 다른 어떤 직무와 비교해 보면 보수나 지분(equity), 현금(cash) 등 모든 면에서 두세 배(2~3배) 차이가 나요. 그렇게 보면 이 엄청나게 비싼 자원을 신경 써서 지원하고 잘 활용하지 않는다면, 솔직히 그건 죄나 마찬가지예요.
text_zh: 工程师绝对是公司里最贵的资源，没有之一，对吧？你看看工程师的配置，还有产品经理(PM)，跟其他岗位比起来，股权啊现金啊什么的，都是人家的两三倍。这么想的话，要是你不好好照顾这些最贵的宝贝疙瘩，不充分利用他们，那简直就是暴殄天物啊。
text_es: Los ingenieros son, por mucho, el recurso más caro de la empresa. Y cuando digo por mucho, es en serio, ¿verdad? O sea, si te fijas en la composición de ingenieros versus... y PMs versus cualquier otra función, estamos hablando de dos a tres veces más - acciones, efectivo, todo. Y si lo ves de esa manera, pues si no estás cuidando y alimentando y no estás aprovechando al máximo este recurso tan caro e increíble, eso es un crimen.

text: I always feel that you should hire to solve a problem you're facing. You should never hire... Or you feel you're going to face. But especially I think just over-hiring, especially... You want to be efficient and smaller teams are always good. Smaller companies are always good, part of the problem.
speaker: Gokul Rajaram
context: Lenny asks what signals indicate it's time to hire a PM beyond the 8-10 engineer rule of thumb. Gokul emphasizes a fundamental hiring principle - only hire when you have a specific problem that needs solving, rather than hiring preemptively. He warns against over-hiring and stresses that maintaining lean, efficient teams is crucial for startup success.
text_ko: 저는 항상 지금 당면한 문제를 해결하려고 사람을 뽑아야 한다고 생각해요. 앞으로 닥칠 것 같아서 미리 뽑는 건 하지 말아야 해요. 특히 과잉 채용(over-hiring)은 정말 문제라고 봐요. 효율적으로 운영하려면 팀은 작을수록 좋고, 작은 조직이 더 잘 돌아가는 경우가 많아요. 과도한 채용이 문제의 한 부분이기도 해요.
text_zh: 我一直觉得吧，招人应该是为了解决你现在面临的问题。千万别为了...或者说你觉得可能会遇到的问题就招人。特别是那种过度招聘，真的...你得追求效率，小团队总是好的。小公司也总是有优势的，这也是问题的一部分。
text_es: Siempre pienso que debes contratar para resolver un problema que tienes encima. Nunca deberías contratar... O que sientes que vas a enfrentar. Pero sobre todo creo que contratar de más, especialmente... Quieres ser eficiente y los equipos pequeños siempre funcionan bien. Las empresas pequeñas siempre son buenas, parte del problema.

text: I think once you have three to four PMs, you do want those three to four PMs to report to a functional product leader just because I feel they want a mentor, first of all. They want a coach. And you want to build a product culture and hopefully discipline across those four or five PMs because the leverage you get.
speaker: Gokul Rajaram
context: Lenny asks about organizational structures as PM teams grow, specifically when PMs should report to a CPO versus a GM. Gokul explains that once you reach 3-4 PMs, they need a dedicated functional leader who can mentor them and build consistent product culture and practices across the team, rather than reporting to a GM who manages multiple functions.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 프로덕트 매니저들(PMs)이 세 명에서 네 명 정도로 늘어나면, 그분들이 실무 중심의 프로덕트 리더(functional product leader)에게 보고하게 하는 게 좋아요. 우선 멘토가 필요하고, 코치도 원하거든요. 또 그 네다섯 명의 프로덕트 매니저들 사이에 프로덕트 문화(product culture)와 어느 정도의 규율을 만들어야 해요. 그래야 얻는 레버리지(leverage)가 커요.
text_zh: 我觉得一旦你有三四个产品经理(PM)的时候，你肯定希望这三四个PM都汇报给一个专门负责产品的领导，因为我感觉他们首先需要一个导师嘛，需要有人指导他们。而且你也想在这四五个PM中间建立起产品文化，最好还能形成一套规范，这样你能发挥出来的杠杆效应就大了。
text_es: Yo creo que una vez que tienes tres o cuatro PMs, sí quieres que esos tres o cuatro PMs le reporten a un líder funcional de producto, principalmente porque siento que necesitan un mentor, para empezar. Necesitan un coach. Y quieres crear una cultura de producto y ojalá disciplina entre esos cuatro o cinco PMs por todo el leverage que obtienes.

text: When companies ask me... Because the number one, if you ever ask a company, 'What's the thing that's keeping you up at night?' They'll always say one of the things always that's keeping them at night, 'I want to hire a leader for X, Y, Z function.' And I never respond with, here's a person. I'll always say, 'Well, you're in this space selling to this kind of customer or serving this kind of customer. Let's think about the best in class companies, who's also, who's very good at functionally the thing you're hiring for, serving the similar type of customer.'
speaker: Gokul Rajaram
context: Lenny asks about Gokul's approach to helping companies hire leaders, referencing a popular Twitter thread. Gokul explains his methodology - instead of recommending specific people, he helps companies identify best-in-class companies that excel at the function they're hiring for while serving similar customer types. This allows them to target the right talent pools rather than just looking at direct competitors.
text_ko: 기업들이 제게 물어볼 때가 있어요. 사실 가장 흔한 질문이 뭔지 아세요? 회사에 '요즘 밤잠을 설치게 하는 게 뭐예요?'라고 물어보면 거의 항상 돌아오는 답이 있어요. 'X, Y, Z 기능(function)을 맡을 리더를 뽑고 싶어요.' 저는 절대 '이 사람이요' 하며 특정 인물을 바로 제안하지 않아요. 대신에 이렇게 말해요. '지금 여러분은 이 분야에서 이런 유형의 고객에게 판매(selling)하거나 서비스를 제공하고 있으니, 같은 유형의 고객을 잘 상대하면서도 기능적으로 여러분이 찾는 일을 잘 해내는 '베스트 인 클래스(best-in-class)' 회사를 함께 생각해 봅시다.'
text_zh: 每当公司来找我的时候...因为第一点，如果你问任何一家公司，"什么事情让你夜不能寐？"他们总是会说其中一件让他们睡不着的事就是，"我想为某某某职能招一个领导。"我从来不会直接回答说，这里有个人选。我总是会说，"好，你们在这个领域，服务的是这类客户。咱们想想那些最顶尖的公司，谁在你们要招的这个职能上做得特别好，而且服务的也是类似的客户群体。"
text_es: Cuando las empresas me consultan... Porque lo número uno, si alguna vez le preguntas a una empresa '¿Qué es lo que no te deja dormir por las noches?', siempre van a decir una de las cosas que los desvela: 'Quiero contratar a un líder para tal o cual función.' Y yo nunca respondo con 'aquí tienes a esta persona.' Siempre les digo: 'Bueno, ustedes están en este sector vendiendo a este tipo de cliente o atendiendo a este tipo de cliente. Pensemos en las empresas que son referentes en el mercado, ¿quién es realmente bueno funcionalmente en lo que están buscando contratar y que atiende a un tipo de cliente similar?'
